Moduli of parabolic subgroups

Mar 16, 2020

In this post, I’d like to talk about the moduli of parabolic subgroups of a connected split semisimple algebraic group. What I’m writing here will appear in the paper that I’m writing which I discussed here. Recall that if is a reductive algebraic group over a field , then the set of Borels in is in bijection with , where is a fixed Borel in and is the associated flag variety. The flag variety, which we’ll denote admits an action of , and if is a maximal torus in , then the fixed points classifies Borels in containing .

Here’s the motivating question: fix a maximal torus . Is there a moduli stack classifying conjugacy classes of parabolic subgroups of which contain ? The answer turns out to be yes, and it’s actually a special case of the construction described in this post.

Let’s work out the question in the universally simple example: , and is the usual diagonal subgroup in . Then there are only three conjugacy classes of parabolic subgroups containing : the Borel of upper triangular matrices, the Borel of lower triangular matrices, and the entirety of . (You could sit down and try to explicitly work out what happens for : you’d find that there are conjugacy classes of parabolic subgroups in . I would not recommend doing this calculation.)

How do we understand parabolic subgroups? Let’s first recall a result which sort of reduces us to combinatorics. Fix a Borel subgroup . Let (resp. ) denote the lattice of weights (resp. coweights), and let (resp. ) denote the lattice of positive weights (resp. dominant coweights) determined by . Let denote a set of simple roots, i.e., a base for the root system. Then conjugacy classes of parabolic subgroups containing are in bijection with subsets of . We can actually characterize the subsets of in terms of a certain partially ordered abelian group.

Equip with the Bruhat ordering, so if is a sum of dominant coroots. Then, a simple combinatorial exercise shows that faces of the monoid are in bijection with subsets of (where “face” means the notion discussed in the previous post). This is great: the main result of the previous post shows that if denotes the group completion of , then the underlying space of is homeomorphic (and in particular admits a bijection) to the set of faces of .

In summary, if is a connected split semisimple group and is a chosen Borel in , then the underlying space of when is the group completion of is in bijection with the set of parabolic subgroups of containing the chosen Borel.

Aha! Now we can see what’s going in the example. For each of the Borels and , there are only two parabolics in containing that Borel: the Borel itself, and the entirety of . These correspond to the closed point and the generic point of . What, then, corresponds to the moduli stack of parabolics containing a fixed maximal torus (and not necessarily a chosen Borel)? In the case of , the moduli of parabolics containing should be obtained by gluing two copies of . Let’s think about what’s going on at the level of underlying spaces.

In other words, the underlying space of is the underlying space of — it contains three points, two of which are closed, and the third of which is a generic point. These points correspond to the two Borel subgroups of , and the entirety of itself (there are no other parabolic subgroups). In fact, when , the stack to be defined below is itself.

For a general connected split semisimple group , a construction of the “parabolic stack” was provided by Procesi and Dolgachev-Lunts. We begin by recalling a general procedure for gluing the stacks in a certain special case. Let be a fan. For each cone , let denote the monoid . There is an associated spectral affine scheme and an associated group scheme acting on . If are cones such that is a face of , then is obtained by localizing at the face . It follows that there is an open immersion which is equivariant for the action of . Just as in with classical toric varieties, the data of the inclusions of cones in the fan specify the data necessary to glue the resulting stacks to form a stack .

Similarly, we may associate the space to each cone , and the data of the inclusions of cones in the fan specify the data necessary to glue the spaces to form a space . These constructions are functorial in the fan : if is a morphism of fans, then there is an induced morphism of stacks and an induced morphism of spaces. Moreover, the theorem in this post implies that the underlying space of the stack is homeomorphic to .

Observe that the underlying space of is homeomorphic to . The space is obtained by gluing for each face of a Weyl chamber, where is defined as in the above construction. If is a Weyl chamber of the root system corresponding to a Borel subgroup containing , then a face of corresponds to a conjugacy class of parabolic subgroups of containing . More precisely, for each Weyl chamber , there is a morphism ; the underlying space of is homeomorphic to , and hence by the above discussion, points of are conjugacy classes of parabolic subgroups of which contain the Borel corresponding to the Weyl chamber . A common face of two Weyl chambers corresponds to a parabolic subgroup containing the Borel subgroups associated to the Weyl chambers. It is in this sense that when is a connected split semisimple group, points of correspond to conjugacy classes of parabolic subgroups of which contain the maximal torus .
